folder: Battery Park., Manhattan, NY
text:
Battery Park: A view limited to the present Aquarium and which at the time of the photograph was the Emigrant Landing office "Castle Garden". Erected in 1807 as Castle Clinton it was ceded to the city in 1822 and leased as a place of amusement.  In May 1855 it was placed in the depicted use, continuing the same until the fire of May 23, 1870.  Rebuilt internally it was used for concerts for a short time.  The Park Commissioner then altered it for its present purpose.
Between 1855 & 70
Gift of Urbrook Collection
title: Manhattan: Battery Park.

folder: Battery Park & [Aquarium]., Manhattan, NY
text:
Battery Park: The present Aquarium at the time when it was the Emigrant Landing Office "Castle Garden". It was erected in 1807 and known as "Castle Clinton".  Ceded to the City in 1822, it was leased as a place of amusement.  Various celebrities appeared here, including the world wide renowned Jenny Lind.  It was placed in the depicted service in 1855, continuing until the fire of May 23, 1870.  Rebuilt internally, it was used for concerts for several years.  The Park Commissioner had it altered to its present form.
Between 1855-70.

Gift of Urbrook Collection
title: Manhattan: Battery Park - [Aquarium].

About 1905

folder: Battery Park., Manhattan, NY
text:
Battery Park: The monument erected by the city in 1818 to mark the S.W. bastion of Fort George. It disappeared in some mysterious manner, probably during the filling in of the Battery in 1851. It was unearthed during the excavations for the subway, and was replaced near the sidewalk in the grounds of the park in 1907. It is now in the N.Y.H. Society, Aug. 1942, S.V.

Sept. 1, 1904.

Gift of W. Jerone Daly
Sec't., Board of Transportation City of New York
William B. Parsons Collection

folder: Battery Park., Manhattan, NY
text:
Battery Park: A northward view towards its building outline at Battery Place, extending from West Street on the left to Broadway on the right.  View No. 1 shows the outstanding structures identified as the Whitehall, the Washington, the Bowling Green, the U.S. Customs House, the Battery Park and the Chesebrough buildings.  View No. 21 includes the annex to the Whitehall Building and the West Street building.  Note the Singer Tower at the right.  At the right margin of View No. 3 is the Standard Oil Building.  The Downtown Athletic Club and an adjoining structure appear in No. 4.

1: 1905
2: 1911
3: 1929, august
4: 1930, July

George L. Balgue, photo

text:
North (Hudson) River, at Battery Park, showing part of Lower Manhattan's skyline as viewed in a northerly direction from a point on the river. In the center is visible the circular New York Aquarium and slightly to its left, the two units (20 and 32-stories) of the Whitehall Building. About 1916.

folder: Battery Park & Aquarium., Manhattan, NY
text:
Battery Park: A set of 4 views of the Aquarium, located in the southwestern corner of the Park at the waters edge.  This structure was completed in 1805 as Fort Clinton, subsequently known as Castle Garden during which period (1822-1855) numerous celebrities performed here.  In 1855 it became the State Immigrant Depot and nearly ten millions of immigrants passed through its walls.  In 1893, these duties being assured by the federal government, it was ?? for the new Depot on Ellis Island and became the present Aquarium in 1896 under the direction of the New York Zoological Society.
Aug 11, 1923
Views 2&3-October 1928
View 4-May 1929
Eugene L Armbruster Collection.

title: North (Hudson) River - Shore and skyline - Manhattan - Battery - 14th Street.

text:
A general view of lower Manhattan as photographed northward from over the Upper Bay. In the foreground is Battery Park, the Aquarium, South Ferry and its "El's", etc. Broadway, beginning at Bowling Green, divides the center. At the left is the marginal West Street, paralleling the shore of the North (Hudson) River. The three outstanding buildings at this date are the Singer, Woolworth and Municipal Bldgs.

About 1925

Ewing Galloway

folder: Battery Park., Manhattan, NY
text:
Battery Park and its surrounding office structures as viewed northward from the waters edge.  Broadway is thru the center where the dominant Standard Oil Building appears.  This overlooks the Washington, Custom House and Cheseborough buildings.  In the background are the Irving Trust, Equitable Trust, Bank of Manhattan and the City Bank Farmers Trust buildings.  Note the old Elevated Line winding its way around the park to enter Greenwich Street.

October 1928
August 1929
February 1931

George L. Balgue

text:
General view of Lower Manhattan. This aerial photograph is northward from a point over the Upper Bay, formed by the confluence of the East (right) and North (left) Rivers. South Ferry and Battery Park are in the foreground. Thru the left center runs Broadway. Upon same and dominant is the towering Woolworth Building. At the right is the Municipal Building.

Copyrighted by
Major Hamilton Maxwell

About 1928

text:
General View--Lower Manhattan, Financial District: Shown are three views of the city's financial area. View 1 is toward the East River from Whitehall Building and shows prominently the Standard Oil and the International Telephone (flag) Buildings. In the foreground is the old tower of the Produce Exchange. Brooklyn is in the background.

View 2 is southwestward across Battery Park and the Acquarium. The Standard Oil Building is on the right and on the left is the City Bank Farmers Trust Building.

View 3 is westward and shows the West Street Building at Albany Street, one of the earliest skyscrapers.

P. L. Sperr

View 1: 1929
View 3: 1933

folder: Battery Park at Ellis Island Ferry House., Manhattan, NY
text:
Battery Park, at the Ellis Island Ferry House, view east.  The woman in the foreground is a fortune teller, for a nominal fee her parrot will pick you a printed card out of the box and on it you may read future weal or woe. You will probably be offered your choice of three or four different languages.
In the background is the South Ferry elevated station, where all four elevated lines have a united southern terminal.
August 28, 1932.
P.L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Battery Park at Ellis Island Ferry House.

folder: Between Pine and Cedar Streets - 60 Wall Street Tower (South)., Manhattan, NY
text:
70 Pine Street, (Sixty Wall Tower): west side of Pearl Street, from Pine to Cedar Streets, showing a general view southward towards the Upper Bay.

In the center is Battery Park and the Aquarium. Note the ships leaving and entering the North (Hudson) River. This is on the right and flows onward towards the Statue of Liberty; the State of New Jersey forming its other side. The buildings in the foreground are at the southerly tip of Manhattan and constitute a part of the business and financial district. The City Bank-Farmers 'Trust' Tower, at the left, overshadows the rectangular Produce Exchange and the U. S. Custom House. To the right is the Standard Oil structure.

April 13, 1933
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - [Manhattan - Between Pine and Cedar Streets - 60 Wall Street Tower (South).]

folder: Governors Island, New York, N.Y.
text:
Governors Island: A birds eye view of same as seen from the Bank of Manhattan Building (No. 40 Wall Street) and across that area of lower Manhattan between Coenties Slip (left) and Battery Park (right). In the left foreground appears Brooklyn with its Gowanus Bay. Separating the Island from same is Buttermilk Channel. Surrounding waters constitute New York's Upper Bay.

Note in the background the hump like formation of Staten Island and the watery passageway to the Lower Bay.

View 2 is similar, from atop the 60 Wall Street Tower (No. 70 Pine Street) and eliminating the Manhattan foreground.

View 1: March 24, 1933
View 2: September 8, 1937

P. L. Sperr
title: Islands - Governor's Island - [Aerial View ; Lower Manhattan ; Bank of Manhattan Building].

September 16, 1936.
P.L. Sperr.

folder: Battery Park & The Firehouse., Manhattan, NY
text:
Battery Park: The firehouse at the Battery that provides a base for the several fireboats serving the City. No records of its construction can be found and it probably dates from the same time as the Park, 1886. In the background of same appears the rear of the circular aquarium. This photo was reproduced on page 30 in the published volume "Changing New York."

May 12, 1936

Berenice Abbott, photo
Federal Art Project

folder: Battery Park & [Shore and skyline.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Battery Park, its embankadero and excursion steamers nestling at the tip of Manhattan and washed by the confluence of the Hudson and East Rivers. Thru the center is the Broadway canyon and its towering office buildings. Pyramiding to the right are the Wall Street structures, dominated by the lofty Bank of Manhattan and the City Bank-Farmers Trust Co. Buildings.

1938-9

Alexander Alland

folder: Battery Park., Manhattan, NY
text:
Battery Park: The Bulletin Board that was presented to the City by John D. Reilly, the head of the Todd Ship Yards. This is a constant source of interest to business men, employees, visitors and others, emphasizing the importance of New York as a great sea port. In the background are the various structures forming the well known skyline. Prominent among these are the Irving Trust, the Standard Oil, and the Bank of Manhattan buildings.
The New York Herald-Tribune of November 12, 1939, Section VII (gravure) carried a similar view.

P. L. Sperr

July 28, 1939
title: Manhattan: Battery Park.
